abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Rice Productivity
            Improvement Project for Laos were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: seed
            production is suitable for more advanced farmers. Lessons
            learned from the project show that significantly longer
            capacity building support than just two cropping seasons is
            required to establish strong seed producer groups. It is
            therefore suggested that seed multiplication activities be
            combined with parallel extension scale-up support for larger
            numbers of farmers, using some small seed packages produced
            under the project. This approach is now being piloted under
            Lao Upland Food Security Improvement Project (LUFSIP). It is
            necessary to avoid ambiguity in the central objectives of an
            'emergency operation' to be supported by the
            Global Food Crisis Response Program (GFRP) or any other Bank
            window, to ensure the most efficient design and
            implementation arrangements. If focus is strictly on one-off
            short-term measures of an emergency nature, project design
            should avoid activities whose efficiency may be negatively
            affected by broader structural institutional and policy
            issues, and the most efficient existing implementation and
            delivery mechanisms should be used.

15619300.projn:
LA-Lao Pdr:  Rice Productivity Improvement
            Project -- P114617

repnme.cdata!:
Lao People's Democratic Republic -
            Rice Productivity Improvement Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Rice Productivity
            Improvement Project for Lao People's Democratic
            Republic (Lao PDR) is to increase rice productivity and
            overall volume of rice production among smallholders in
            selected provinces, thereby increasing incomes and improving
            food security for small farm households. The project was
            approved on January 13, 2009 and was processed under the
            Global Food Crisis Response Program in the amount of US$3
            million. The Project Development Objective (PDO) is to
            increase rice productivity and overall volume of rice
            production among smallholders in selected provinces, thereby
            increasing incomes and improving food security for small
            farm households. After initial implementation difficulties,
            the current progress towards achievement of PDO and
            implementation progress are being upgraded to Marginally
            Satisfactory following the implementation support mission
            held in November 2011. The project has produced significant
            amounts of seed, and the use of good seed has contributed
            significantly to increasing rice yields and the total
            production volume of rice. The availability of improved seed
            is helping farmers increase rice productivity and the
            overall volume of production. The project objectives remain
            relevant and achievable. The changes have no impact on the
            PDO, results/ indicators, scope of project components,
            project institutional arrangements, safeguards, disbursement
            and fiduciary arrangements. The borrower has prepared an
            action plan satisfactory to the Bank to complete the project.

13910252.projn:
LA-Lao Pdr:  Rice Productivity Improvement
            Project -- P114617
13910252.admreg: East Asia and Pacific,East Asia and Pacific

repnme.cdata!:
Lao People's Democratic Republic -
            Rice Productivity Improvement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Rice Productivity
            Improvement Project for Lao People's Democratic
            Republic (Lao PDR) is to increase rice productivity and
            overall volume of rice production among smallholders in
            selected provinces, thereby increasing incomes and improving
            food security for small farm households. This will result in
            reducing the seasonal and disaster related shortages of rice
            in the short run, as well as reducing the impacts of rising
            food prices. Lao PDR faces serious challenges in addressing
            food security, with parts of the population also facing the
            compounded effects of food and agricultural input price
            surges, and the recent flood disaster. In order to assist
            Lao PDR to respond rapidly to its food security challenges,
            the World Bank proposes to provide emergency support for:
            (i) a rapid improvement in agricultural productivity to
            increase food security at the household and village levels;
            and (ii) a nutritional improvement project to complement
            existing financing of the Lao PDR Health Improvement Project.
